author: Spencer Jakab
title: The Case for Buying GE (Yes, Really)
description: General Electric has frustrated bottom-pickers for the past year, but a rational approach suggests it could either be worth a whole lot more—or possibly nothing at all.
content: General Electric, once the worlds most valuable company, might be worthless. But what if this is precisely the time to buy? The last time GE shares got this low was at the depth of the financial crisis when there was a real chance that its huge financial arm,… [+4331 chars]
fulltext:
General Electric, once the world’s most valuable company, might be worthless.

But what if this is precisely the time to buy? The last time GE shares got this low was at the depth of the financial crisis when there was a real chance that its huge financial arm, GE Capital, would bring down the whole enterprise. Investors willing to take that risk could at one point snap up its valuable industrial operations for free.

Industrial companies don’t implode the way financial firms do. So, despite the 40% selloff in the past month, the chances of catastrophe at the largely industrial GE are much less likely.

The odds of a bankruptcy recently topped 15% if credit-default-swap prices were to be believed. On the other hand, GE’s industrial operations are now a mixed bag—booming aviation and health care units, a listed oil-and-gas unit trading near multiyear lows and a horror show in its largest unit, power.

It is little wonder that optimists who saw the glass as at least 85% full have been burned by abortive rallies. Just seven weeks ago, there was a 21% gain in six trading sessions topping out at $13.61 a share on optimism over Chief Executive Larry Culp’s appointment. GE shares closed Friday at $7.57.

Buying GE because you think its shares are destined to return to that last, or any other recent high, is a mistake. This is called anchoring and it is one of the psychological foibles that part fools from their money. The rational approach is to value GE as a going concern, acknowledging that there is at least a small chance of losing everything. If you like your odds, then buy it.

It is never easy to pull the trigger on a beaten-up stock. GE requires even more fortitude. Government investigations into its accounting, a massive write-down in its power division and the possibility it will have to pour more cash into its discontinued long-term-care insurance operation are just the known unknowns. While its debt isn’t rated junk, it trades like it is—hence the elevated price of credit default swaps.

Imagination at Work Sum-of-the parts valuation of GE based on peer groups, dollars a share Power $6.59 a share Aviation 4.68 Healthcare 4.39 Baker Hughes 3.35 Renewables 1.38 Transportation 1.13 Lighting 0.19 Finance less debt -3.15 Net industrial debt -4.64 Other* -2.07 Tuesday share price: $11.84 Sum of the parts $7.65

New York University finance professor Aswath Damodaran, who literally wrote the book on valuation, recently used two different approaches that rely on each of GE’s division’s past operating income and the multiples of close peers to arrive at per-share values of $11.84 or $10.92 a share. It was an exercise not without frustration.

“I have always described my vision of hell as having to value GE over and over and over again, for eternity,” he wrote.

Buying GE based only on its past accounting earnings, now under investigation, could have fairly hellish results if it turns out they were overstated. An alternative to Mr. Damodaran’s approach is to focus on cash, which is harder to fudge. GE’s free-cash-flow margin since 2000, a period encompassing two deep recessions, has averaged 11.2%. Plug in actual analyst cash-flow forecasts for the next two years and apply the historical margin to GE’s revenue from 2021 onward, assuming sales just grow in line with the economy. Discount those cash flows and subtract liabilities such as GE’s pension deficit, net debt and a further $15 billion contribution to long-term-care insurance produces a value per share of $19.42. GE fetched as much a little over a year ago.

But that is still optimistic. One reason is that before the last recession, high-margin businesses like entertainment and finance combined for nearly half of GE’s revenue. Last year, that was just 7%. Meanwhile, GE management can’t pin down when its biggest division, power, will turn around. Finally, a long-term cash-flow valuation is pretty useless for a company that goes bust in the short term.

There is no easy way to account for all of that except to build in a margin of safety. One approach would be to assign equal odds to the company going bankrupt or earning its historical free-cash-flow margin—15% each—and placing 70% odds on it earning just three-quarters of its historical free-cash-flow margin. On a probability-weighted basis, the stock should be worth $10.90 or 42% more than it is today.

Valuation is as much art as science. Faulty assumptions in a financial model, as analysts say, equals “garbage in, garbage out.” Even so, there is reason to believe that there is treasure to be found in this corporate dumpster fire.
